trans-unit.source: Relying Party Applications
trans-unit.target: Relying Party Applications

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: Relying Party Applications
trans-unit.target: Relying Party Applications

trans-unit.source: A <newTerm>relying party application</newTerm> (also known as a <newTerm>claims-aware application</newTerm> or <newTerm>claims-based application</newTerm>) is an application or service that relies on claims for authentication.
trans-unit.target: A <newTerm>relying party application</newTerm> (also known as a <newTerm>claims-aware application</newTerm> or <newTerm>claims-based application</newTerm>) is an application or service that relies on claims for authentication.

trans-unit.source: In <token>firstref_acs</token>, a <newTerm>relying party application</newTerm> is a web site, an application, or a service that uses <token>secondref_acs</token> to implement federated authentication.
trans-unit.target: In <token>firstref_acs</token>, a <newTerm>relying party application</newTerm> is a web site, an application, or a service that uses <token>secondref_acs</token> to implement federated authentication.

trans-unit.source: You can create and configure relying party applications manually, by using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, or programmatically, by using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service.
trans-unit.target: You can create and configure relying party applications manually, by using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, or programmatically, by using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service.

trans-unit.source: In the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, the relying party application that you add and configure is a logical representation of your web site, application, or service that trusts a specific <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: In the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, the relying party application that you add and configure is a logical representation of your web site, application, or service that trusts a specific <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: You can add and configure many relying party applications in each <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: You can add and configure many relying party applications in each <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: Configuring in the ACS Management Portal
trans-unit.target: Configuring in the ACS Management Portal

trans-unit.source: You can use the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal to configure the following properties of a relying party application:
trans-unit.target: You can use the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal to configure the following properties of a relying party application:

trans-unit.source: Mode
trans-unit.target: Mode

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Mode</ui> property determines whether you configure your relying party application settings manually or specify a WS-Federation metadata document that defines the application settings.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Mode</ui> property determines whether you configure your relying party application settings manually or specify a WS-Federation metadata document that defines the application settings.

trans-unit.source: A WS-Federation metadata document typically contains an application's realm and return URL.
trans-unit.target: A WS-Federation metadata document typically contains an application's realm and return URL.

trans-unit.source: It can also include an optional encryption certificate that is used to encrypt the tokens that ACS issues for the application.
trans-unit.target: It can also include an optional encryption certificate that is used to encrypt the tokens that ACS issues for the application.

trans-unit.source: If a WS-Federation document is specified and the metadata contains an encryption certificate, the <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_4" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Encryption Policy</link> setting defaults to <ui>Require Encryption</ui>.
trans-unit.target: If a WS-Federation document is specified and the metadata contains an encryption certificate, the <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_4" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Encryption Policy</link> setting defaults to <ui>Require Encryption</ui>.

trans-unit.source: If the value of the <ui>Token Encryption Policy</ui> setting is <ui>Require Encryption</ui>, but the WS-Federation metadata document does not include an encryption certificate, you must upload an encryption certificate manually.
trans-unit.target: If the value of the <ui>Token Encryption Policy</ui> setting is <ui>Require Encryption</ui>, but the WS-Federation metadata document does not include an encryption certificate, you must upload an encryption certificate manually.

trans-unit.source: If your relying party application is integrated with Windows Identity Foundation (WIF), WIF automatically creates a WS-Federation metadata document for your application.
trans-unit.target: If your relying party application is integrated with Windows Identity Foundation (WIF), WIF automatically creates a WS-Federation metadata document for your application.

trans-unit.source: Realm and Return URL
trans-unit.target: Realm and Return URL

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Realm</ui> property defines the URI in which the tokens issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> are valid.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Realm</ui> property defines the URI in which the tokens issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> are valid.

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Return URL</ui> (also known as the <newTerm>ReplyTo address</newTerm>) defines the URL to which the <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens are sent.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Return URL</ui> (also known as the <newTerm>ReplyTo address</newTerm>) defines the URL to which the <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens are sent.

trans-unit.source: When a token is requested for access to the relying party application, <token>secondref_acs</token> issues the token only when the realm in the token request matches the realm of the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: When a token is requested for access to the relying party application, <token>secondref_acs</token> issues the token only when the realm in the token request matches the realm of the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, realm values are case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, realm values are case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: In the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, you can configure only one realm and one return URL in each <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: In the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, you can configure only one realm and one return URL in each <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: In the simplest case, the realm and Return URL are identical.
trans-unit.target: In the simplest case, the realm and Return URL are identical.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the root URI of your application is https://contoso.com, the Realm and Return URL of the relying party application are https://contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the root URI of your application is https://contoso.com, the Realm and Return URL of the relying party application are https://contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: To configure more than one return URL (ReplyTo address) for a relying party application, use the <link xlink:href="15767154-c714-4690-be6f-3a0537e7ef61" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RelyingPartyAddress</link> entity in the ACS Management Service.
trans-unit.target: To configure more than one return URL (ReplyTo address) for a relying party application, use the <link xlink:href="15767154-c714-4690-be6f-3a0537e7ef61" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RelyingPartyAddress</link> entity in the ACS Management Service.

trans-unit.source: When a token is requested from <token>secondref_acs</token> or a token is posted to <token>secondref_acs</token> from an identity provider, <token>secondref_acs</token> compares the realm value in the token request to the realm values for the relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: When a token is requested from <token>secondref_acs</token> or a token is posted to <token>secondref_acs</token> from an identity provider, <token>secondref_acs</token> compares the realm value in the token request to the realm values for the relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: If the token request uses WS-Federation protocol, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the realm value is in the <parameterReference>wtrealm</parameterReference> parameter.
trans-unit.target: If the token request uses WS-Federation protocol, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the realm value is in the <parameterReference>wtrealm</parameterReference> parameter.

trans-unit.source: If the token uses OAuth WRAP protocol, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the realm value in the <parameterReference>applies_to</parameterReference> parameter.
trans-unit.target: If the token uses OAuth WRAP protocol, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the realm value in the <parameterReference>applies_to</parameterReference> parameter.

trans-unit.source: If <token>secondref_acs</token> finds a matching realm in the configuration settings for a relying party application, it creates a token that authenticates the user to the relying party application and sends the token to the Return URL.
trans-unit.target: If <token>secondref_acs</token> finds a matching realm in the configuration settings for a relying party application, it creates a token that authenticates the user to the relying party application and sends the token to the Return URL.

trans-unit.source: The process is the similar when the relying party has more than one Return URL.
trans-unit.target: The process is the similar when the relying party has more than one Return URL.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_ACS</token> gets the redirect URL from the <parameterReference>wreply</parameterReference> parameter.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_ACS</token> gets the redirect URL from the <parameterReference>wreply</parameterReference> parameter.

trans-unit.source: If the redirect URL is one of the Return URLs for the relying party application, ACS sends the response to that URL.
trans-unit.target: If the redirect URL is one of the Return URLs for the relying party application, ACS sends the response to that URL.

trans-unit.source: Realm values are case sensitive.
trans-unit.target: Realm values are case sensitive.

trans-unit.source: The token is issued only if the realm values are identical or the realm value for the relying party application is a prefix of the realm in the token request.
trans-unit.target: The token is issued only if the realm values are identical or the realm value for the relying party application is a prefix of the realm in the token request.

trans-unit.source: For example, the relying party application realm value of <userInput>http://www.fabrikam.com</userInput> matches a token request realm value of <userInput>http://www.fabrikam.com/billing</userInput>, but it does not match a token request realm v of <userInput>http://fabrikam.com</userInput>.
trans-unit.target: For example, the relying party application realm value of <userInput>http://www.fabrikam.com</userInput> matches a token request realm value of <userInput>http://www.fabrikam.com/billing</userInput>, but it does not match a token request realm v of <userInput>http://fabrikam.com</userInput>.

trans-unit.source: Error URL (optional)
trans-unit.target: Error URL (optional)

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Error URL</ui> specifies a URL to which <token>secondref_acs</token> redirects users if an error occurs during the login process.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Error URL</ui> specifies a URL to which <token>secondref_acs</token> redirects users if an error occurs during the login process.

trans-unit.source: It is an optional property of the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: It is an optional property of the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Error URL</ui> value can be a custom page hosted by the relying party application, such as http://www.fabrikam.com/billing/error.aspx.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Error URL</ui> value can be a custom page hosted by the relying party application, such as http://www.fabrikam.com/billing/error.aspx.

trans-unit.source: As part of the redirect, <token>secondref_acs</token> supplies details about the error to the relying party application as a JSON-encoded HTTP URL parameter.
trans-unit.target: As part of the redirect, <token>secondref_acs</token> supplies details about the error to the relying party application as a JSON-encoded HTTP URL parameter.

trans-unit.source: The custom error page can be crafted to interpret the JSON-encoded error information, to render the actual error message, and/or to display static help text.
trans-unit.target: The custom error page can be crafted to interpret the JSON-encoded error information, to render the actual error message, and/or to display static help text.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the Error URL usage, see <link xlink:href="fcc26f6c-da98-439f-99ba-55489679f871" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Code Sample: ASP.NET Simple MVC 2</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the Error URL usage, see <link xlink:href="fcc26f6c-da98-439f-99ba-55489679f871" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Code Sample: ASP.NET Simple MVC 2</link>.

trans-unit.source: Token Format
trans-unit.target: Token Format

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Token format</ui> property determines the format of the tokens that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Token format</ui> property determines the format of the tokens that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue SAML 2.0, SAML 1.1, SWT, or JWT tokens.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue SAML 2.0, SAML 1.1, SWT, or JWT tokens.

trans-unit.source: For more information about token formats, see <link xlink:href="5fd7e09f-0c5b-4571-943e-c743ee0bac9d" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Formats Supported in ACS 2.0</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about token formats, see <link xlink:href="5fd7e09f-0c5b-4571-943e-c743ee0bac9d" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Formats Supported in ACS 2.0</link>.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> uses standard protocols to return the tokens to a web application or service.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> uses standard protocols to return the tokens to a web application or service.

trans-unit.source: When more than one protocol is supported for a token format, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the same protocol that was used for the token request.
trans-unit.target: When more than one protocol is supported for a token format, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the same protocol that was used for the token request.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> supports the following token format/protocol combinations:
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> supports the following token format/protocol combinations:

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can return SAML 2.0 tokens using WS-Trust and WS-Federation protocols.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can return SAML 2.0 tokens using WS-Trust and WS-Federation protocols.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can return SAML 1.1 tokens using WS-Federation and related WS-Trust protocols.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can return SAML 1.1 tokens using WS-Federation and related WS-Trust protocols.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can return SWT tokens using WS-Federation, WS-Trust, OAuth-WRAP, and OAuth 2.0 protocols.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can return SWT tokens using WS-Federation, WS-Trust, OAuth-WRAP, and OAuth 2.0 protocols.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue and return JWT tokens using WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth 2.0 protocols.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue and return JWT tokens using WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth 2.0 protocols.

trans-unit.source: For more information about standard protocols the <token>secondref_acs</token> uses, see <link xlink:href="ccfc4118-5d5b-4ac0-9dba-d5225cfc6745" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Protocols Supported in ACS 2.0</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about standard protocols the <token>secondref_acs</token> uses, see <link xlink:href="ccfc4118-5d5b-4ac0-9dba-d5225cfc6745" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Protocols Supported in ACS 2.0</link>.

trans-unit.source: When choosing a token format, consider how your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> signs the tokens that it issues.
trans-unit.target: When choosing a token format, consider how your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> signs the tokens that it issues.

trans-unit.source: All <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens must be signed.
trans-unit.target: All <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens must be signed.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Signing</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Signing</link>.

trans-unit.source: Also, consider whether you want the tokens to be encrypted..
trans-unit.target: Also, consider whether you want the tokens to be encrypted..

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_4" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Encryption Policy</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_4" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Encryption Policy</link>.

trans-unit.source: Token Encryption Policy
trans-unit.target: Token Encryption Policy

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Token encryption policy</ui> determines whether the tokens that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues for the relying party application are encrypted.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Token encryption policy</ui> determines whether the tokens that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues for the relying party application are encrypted.

trans-unit.source: To require encryption, select the <ui>Require Encryption</ui> value.
trans-unit.target: To require encryption, select the <ui>Require Encryption</ui> value.

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can configure an encryption policy for SAML 2.0 or SAML 1.1 tokens only.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can configure an encryption policy for SAML 2.0 or SAML 1.1 tokens only.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> does not support encryption of the SWT or JWT tokens.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> does not support encryption of the SWT or JWT tokens.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> encrypts SAML 2.0 and SAML 1.1 tokens using an X.509 certificate containing a public key (.cer file).
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> encrypts SAML 2.0 and SAML 1.1 tokens using an X.509 certificate containing a public key (.cer file).

trans-unit.source: These encrypted tokens are then decrypted by using a private key possessed by the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: These encrypted tokens are then decrypted by using a private key possessed by the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: For more information about getting and using encryption certificates, see <link xlink:href="b75ed5c7-ca81-44a2-8d8d-6a63399f87dd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Certificates and Keys</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about getting and using encryption certificates, see <link xlink:href="b75ed5c7-ca81-44a2-8d8d-6a63399f87dd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Certificates and Keys</link>.

trans-unit.source: Configuring an encryption policy on your <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens is optional.
trans-unit.target: Configuring an encryption policy on your <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens is optional.

trans-unit.source: However, an encryption policy must be configured when your relying party application is a web service that is using proof-of-possession tokens over the WS-Trust protocol.
trans-unit.target: However, an encryption policy must be configured when your relying party application is a web service that is using proof-of-possession tokens over the WS-Trust protocol.

trans-unit.source: This particular scenario does not function properly without encrypted tokens.
trans-unit.target: This particular scenario does not function properly without encrypted tokens.

trans-unit.source: Token Lifetime
trans-unit.target: Token Lifetime

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Token lifetime</ui> property specifies the time interval (in seconds) during which the security token that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues to the relying party application is valid.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Token lifetime</ui> property specifies the time interval (in seconds) during which the security token that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues to the relying party application is valid.

trans-unit.source: The default value is 600 (10 minutes).
trans-unit.target: The default value is 600 (10 minutes).

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, the token lifetime value must be between zero (0) and 86400 (24 hours) inclusive.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, the token lifetime value must be between zero (0) and 86400 (24 hours) inclusive.

trans-unit.source: Identity Providers
trans-unit.target: Identity Providers

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Identity providers</ui> property specifies the identity providers that can send claims to the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Identity providers</ui> property specifies the identity providers that can send claims to the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: These identity providers appear on the <token>secondref_acs</token> login page for your web application or service.
trans-unit.target: These identity providers appear on the <token>secondref_acs</token> login page for your web application or service.

trans-unit.source: All identity providers configured in the <system>Identity providers</system> section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal appear in the identity provider list.
trans-unit.target: All identity providers configured in the <system>Identity providers</system> section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal appear in the identity provider list.

trans-unit.source: To add an identify provider to the list, click <ui>Identity providers</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To add an identify provider to the list, click <ui>Identity providers</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Each relying party application can be associated with zero or more identity providers.
trans-unit.target: Each relying party application can be associated with zero or more identity providers.

trans-unit.source: The relying party applications in an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> can be associated with the same identity provider or different identity providers.
trans-unit.target: The relying party applications in an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> can be associated with the same identity provider or different identity providers.

trans-unit.source: If you do not select any identity providers for a relying party application, you must configure a direct authentication with <token>secondref_acs</token> for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: If you do not select any identity providers for a relying party application, you must configure a direct authentication with <token>secondref_acs</token> for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can use service identities to configure a direct authentication.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can use service identities to configure a direct authentication.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="52225343-ab35-4455-b3f9-e014d7ac6b78" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Service Identities</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="52225343-ab35-4455-b3f9-e014d7ac6b78" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Service Identities</link>.

trans-unit.source: Rule Groups
trans-unit.target: Rule Groups

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Rule groups</ui> property determines which rules the relying party application uses when processing claims.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Rule groups</ui> property determines which rules the relying party application uses when processing claims.

trans-unit.source: Each <token>secondref_acs</token> relying party application must be associated with at least one rule group.
trans-unit.target: Each <token>secondref_acs</token> relying party application must be associated with at least one rule group.

trans-unit.source: If a token request matches a relying party application that has no rule groups, <token>secondref_acs</token> does not issue a token to the web application or service.
trans-unit.target: If a token request matches a relying party application that has no rule groups, <token>secondref_acs</token> does not issue a token to the web application or service.

trans-unit.source: All rule groups configured in the <system>Rule groups</system> section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal appear in the rule group list.
trans-unit.target: All rule groups configured in the <system>Rule groups</system> section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal appear in the rule group list.

trans-unit.source: To add a rule group to the list, click <ui>Rule groups</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To add a rule group to the list, click <ui>Rule groups</ui>.

trans-unit.source: When you add a new relying party application in the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, the <ui>Create New Rule Group</ui> option is selected by default.
trans-unit.target: When you add a new relying party application in the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, the <ui>Create New Rule Group</ui> option is selected by default.

trans-unit.source: It is strongly recommended that you create a new rule group for your new relying party application.
trans-unit.target: It is strongly recommended that you create a new rule group for your new relying party application.

trans-unit.source: However, you can associate your relying party application with an existing rule group.
trans-unit.target: However, you can associate your relying party application with an existing rule group.

trans-unit.source: To do so, clear the <ui>Create New Rule Group</ui> option and select the desired rule group.
trans-unit.target: To do so, clear the <ui>Create New Rule Group</ui> option and select the desired rule group.

trans-unit.source: You can associate a relying party application with more than one rule group (and associate a rule group with more than one relying party application).
trans-unit.target: You can associate a relying party application with more than one rule group (and associate a rule group with more than one relying party application).

trans-unit.source: If a relying party application is associated with more than one rule group, <token>secondref_acs</token> recursively evaluates the rules in all of the rule groups as though they were rules in a single rule group.
trans-unit.target: If a relying party application is associated with more than one rule group, <token>secondref_acs</token> recursively evaluates the rules in all of the rule groups as though they were rules in a single rule group.

trans-unit.source: For more information about rules and rule groups, see <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about rules and rule groups, see <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.

trans-unit.source: Token Signing
trans-unit.target: Token Signing

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Token signing settings</ui> property specifies how the security tokens that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues are signed.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Token signing settings</ui> property specifies how the security tokens that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues are signed.

trans-unit.source: All <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens must be signed.
trans-unit.target: All <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens must be signed.

trans-unit.source: The token signing options that are available depend on the <ui>Token Format</ui> of the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: The token signing options that are available depend on the <ui>Token Format</ui> of the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: (For more information about token formats, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Format</link>.)
trans-unit.target: (For more information about token formats, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Format</link>.)

trans-unit.source: SAML tokens: Use an X.509 certificate to sign tokens.
trans-unit.target: SAML tokens: Use an X.509 certificate to sign tokens.

trans-unit.source: SWT tokens: Use a symmetric key to sign tokens.
trans-unit.target: SWT tokens: Use a symmetric key to sign tokens.

trans-unit.source: JWT tokens: Use either an X.509 certificate or a symmetric key to sign tokens.
trans-unit.target: JWT tokens: Use either an X.509 certificate or a symmetric key to sign tokens.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>X.509 Certificate options</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>X.509 Certificate options</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: The following options are available for tokens signed with an X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: The following options are available for tokens signed with an X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Use service namespace certificate (standard)</ui>If you select this option, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the certificate for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> to sign SAML 1.1 and SAML 2.0 tokens for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Use service namespace certificate (standard)</ui>If you select this option, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the certificate for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> to sign SAML 1.1 and SAML 2.0 tokens for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: Use this option if you plan to automate the configuration of your web application or service using WS-Federation metadata, because the namespace public key is published in the WS-Federation metadata for your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: Use this option if you plan to automate the configuration of your web application or service using WS-Federation metadata, because the namespace public key is published in the WS-Federation metadata for your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: The URL of the WS-Federation Metadata document appears on the <ui>Application Integration</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: The URL of the WS-Federation Metadata document appears on the <ui>Application Integration</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Use dedicated certificate</ui>If you select this option, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses an application-specific certificate to sign SAML 1.1 and SAML 2.0 tokens for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Use dedicated certificate</ui>If you select this option, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses an application-specific certificate to sign SAML 1.1 and SAML 2.0 tokens for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: The certificate is not used for other relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: The certificate is not used for other relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: After you select this option, browse for an X.509 certificate with a private key (.pfx file) and then enter the password for the .pfx file.
trans-unit.target: After you select this option, browse for an X.509 certificate with a private key (.pfx file) and then enter the password for the .pfx file.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>JWT Tokens</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>JWT Tokens</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: When you configure a relying party application to use the X.509 certificate for the Access Control namespace to sign JWT tokens for a relying party application, links to the Access Control namespace certificate and the Access Control namespace key appear on the page for the relying party application in the ACS Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: When you configure a relying party application to use the X.509 certificate for the Access Control namespace to sign JWT tokens for a relying party application, links to the Access Control namespace certificate and the Access Control namespace key appear on the page for the relying party application in the ACS Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: However, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses only the namespace certificate to sign tokens for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: However, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses only the namespace certificate to sign tokens for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Managed Namespaces</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Managed Namespaces</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: When you are adding a relying party application to a managed namespace, such as a Service Bus namespace, do not enter application-specific (dedicated) certificates or keys.
trans-unit.target: When you are adding a relying party application to a managed namespace, such as a Service Bus namespace, do not enter application-specific (dedicated) certificates or keys.

trans-unit.source: Instead, select the options that direct <token>secondref_acs</token> to use the certificates and keys that are configured for all applications in the managed namespace.
trans-unit.target: Instead, select the options that direct <token>secondref_acs</token> to use the certificates and keys that are configured for all applications in the managed namespace.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="3ad43749-6e00-4126-ad87-46a85a9e8f24" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Managed Namespaces</link>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="3ad43749-6e00-4126-ad87-46a85a9e8f24" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Managed Namespaces</link>

trans-unit.source: For more information about shared and dedicated certificates and keys, see <link xlink:href="b75ed5c7-ca81-44a2-8d8d-6a63399f87dd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Certificates and Keys</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about shared and dedicated certificates and keys, see <link xlink:href="b75ed5c7-ca81-44a2-8d8d-6a63399f87dd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Certificates and Keys</link>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Symmetric key options</embeddedLabel>
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Symmetric key options</embeddedLabel>

trans-unit.source: As a security best-practice, when using symmetric keys, create a dedicated key for each relying party application, instead of using the shared symmetric key for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: As a security best-practice, when using symmetric keys, create a dedicated key for each relying party application, instead of using the shared symmetric key for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: If you enter or generate a dedicated key, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses dedicated key to sign tokens for the relying party application as long as the dedicated key is valid.
trans-unit.target: If you enter or generate a dedicated key, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses dedicated key to sign tokens for the relying party application as long as the dedicated key is valid.

trans-unit.source: However, if the dedicated key expires and is not replaced, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the shared namespace key to sign tokens for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: However, if the dedicated key expires and is not replaced, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the shared namespace key to sign tokens for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: If you elect to use the shared symmetric key, copy the values for the <ui>Service Namespace</ui> key from the <ui>Certificates and keys</ui> page and paste them into the fields in the <ui>Token Signing</ui> section of the <ui>Relying party applications</ui> page.
trans-unit.target: If you elect to use the shared symmetric key, copy the values for the <ui>Service Namespace</ui> key from the <ui>Certificates and keys</ui> page and paste them into the fields in the <ui>Token Signing</ui> section of the <ui>Relying party applications</ui> page.

trans-unit.source: The following options are available for tokens signed with symmetric keys.
trans-unit.target: The following options are available for tokens signed with symmetric keys.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Token signing key</embeddedLabel>Enter a 256-bit symmetric key or click <ui>Generate</ui> to generate a 256-bit symmetric key.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Token signing key</embeddedLabel>Enter a 256-bit symmetric key or click <ui>Generate</ui> to generate a 256-bit symmetric key.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Effective date</embeddedLabel>Specifies the starting date of the date range during which the symmetric key is valid.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Effective date</embeddedLabel>Specifies the starting date of the date range during which the symmetric key is valid.

trans-unit.source: Beginning on this date, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the symmetric key to sign tokens for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: Beginning on this date, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the symmetric key to sign tokens for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> default value is the current date.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> default value is the current date.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Expiration date</embeddedLabel> Specifies the ending date of the date range during which the symmetric key is valid.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Expiration date</embeddedLabel> Specifies the ending date of the date range during which the symmetric key is valid.

trans-unit.source: From this date forward, <token>secondref_acs</token> does not use the symmetric key to sign tokens for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: From this date forward, <token>secondref_acs</token> does not use the symmetric key to sign tokens for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: There is no default value.
trans-unit.target: There is no default value.

trans-unit.source: As a security best practice, symmetric keys should be replaced every year or every two years, depending on the requirements of the application.
trans-unit.target: As a security best practice, symmetric keys should be replaced every year or every two years, depending on the requirements of the application.

trans-unit.source: Token Encryption
trans-unit.target: Token Encryption

trans-unit.source: The token encryption certificate option specifies the X.509 certificate (.cer file) that is used to encrypt tokens for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: The token encryption certificate option specifies the X.509 certificate (.cer file) that is used to encrypt tokens for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can encrypt only SAML 2.0 or SAML 1.1 tokens.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can encrypt only SAML 2.0 or SAML 1.1 tokens.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> does not support encryption of SWT or JWT tokens.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> does not support encryption of SWT or JWT tokens.

trans-unit.source: You specify certificates for token encryption in the <ui>Certificates and Keys</ui> section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal.
trans-unit.target: You specify certificates for token encryption in the <ui>Certificates and Keys</ui> section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal.

trans-unit.source: When you click the <ui>Click here</ui> link in the <ui>Token Encryption Policy</ui> section of the Relying party application page, the <ui>Add Token Encryption Certificate</ui> page of Certificates and Keys opens.
trans-unit.target: When you click the <ui>Click here</ui> link in the <ui>Token Encryption Policy</ui> section of the Relying party application page, the <ui>Add Token Encryption Certificate</ui> page of Certificates and Keys opens.

trans-unit.source: Use this page to specify a certificate file.
trans-unit.target: Use this page to specify a certificate file.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_4" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Encryption Policy</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9#BKMK_4" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Encryption Policy</link>.

trans-unit.source: For more information about getting and adding encryption certificates, see <link xlink:href="b75ed5c7-ca81-44a2-8d8d-6a63399f87dd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Certificates and Keys</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about getting and adding encryption certificates, see <link xlink:href="b75ed5c7-ca81-44a2-8d8d-6a63399f87dd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Certificates and Keys</link>.
